Topic.Title: Extremely Overpriced!!!

Message.Msg: The bull case is very weak. It is based on margins stabilizing at what they beleive to be a cycle low (better than expected), and they are banking returns on AMZN last growth cycle after the major re-investment. Last time the stock got hit down hard during the "investment" and then rose more than 3x post that. Bulls poiint to that and don;t want to miss it. Both points are misguided as, as the capex will hit them over the next 8 years, not now. They just burned half their cash in the last 2 Q's - that will hit margins/EPS over next 8 years. Second, they are much bigger now and sales growth will come harder. The point of the capex is to drop distribution cost, not increase revenue. That is why they are in panic and starting a new business every week. This should make all bulls worried, as no company has been successful with this type of buckshot strategy.

Topic.Title: Extremely Overpriced!!!

Message.Msg: But the price of a stock should be fixed into what is going on 6 months from now not 6 years from now! Way to high to fast!

Topic.Title: It can get alot more overpriced.

Message.Msg: "Any company can jack up revenue..." No, actually they can't. They don't have the infrastructure already in place and they don't have the cash to add it takes to expand even more let alone the aggressiveness to risk investing that cash if they had it on this scale. "Once they try to make a profit the revenue growth will come to a screeching halt." Really? They made profits from 2007-2010 or 11 after the previous expansion and investment cycle. Can you point to any evidence to support your claim?

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

Topic.Title: It can get alot more overpriced.

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

Message.Msg: Nope. Ebay is highly profitable. It can cut prices by half and still have positive EPS/cash-flow. If Amazon is forced to cut 3P prices by 50%, it will have to raise cash (probably via equity) or go BK within a year. A price war over 3P seller, as Ebay is currently initiating is a killer for Amazon.

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

Message.Msg: "It can cut prices by half and still have blah, blah...." Yeah, people keep telling me this for what ever company you want to name (fill in the blank). Apple has even more cash. How come they don't charge half as much for their products and put every one out of business? If Ebay wanted to be in a price war they would not be charging $5 for 1 day delivery. They'd be offering it for free or some nominal fee. For Ebay a price war means their margins get killed and their shareholders sell off the stock and their CEO gets fired. This is why Apple can't do the above. Or Walmart. Or Google, etc.

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

Message.Msg: "That's a strange argument to make. You are basically saying that Amazon's advantage is that it's shareholders are ok with subpar margins whereas shareholders of other players wouldn't put up with it. Have I got that right?" Not all shareholders think the same way. If they did everyone would just invest in an index fund. Over time investors who want certain things gravitate to certain stocks. Some kind of investors aren't long-term investors. Those are the type that probably own a stock like Ebay now and would sell it off if they got into a price war. Additionally, Amazon already has the infrastructure in place to handle a certain level of fulfillment services. Ebay's existing infrastructure is about 10 times smaller. It would probably take several years for them to catch up even if they decided to go for zero margins in the meantime. Are you saying that if you were an Ebay investor you would not sell off the stock under those circumstances? I find your reasoning even stranger.

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

Message.Msg: You really don't get it - all these fulfillment centers are loss leaders. Amazon is incapable of generating income from its own sales. Their cost of goods is too high and prices are too low (sales tax will only make this worse). The ONLY profitable part of Amazon's operations is the 3P sellers and eBay launching a price war in the 3P business is absolutely terrible news for Amazon. Ebay is not copying Amazon - that would be stupid. It is competing over the only profitable part of the business. Looking at the current trends, I can see Amazon heading towards an extremely dilutive equity offering in 2013.

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

The likelihood that amzn will ever make money becomes more remote each day.

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

Message.Msg: This is Amazon's advantage, JB isn't worried about getting fired, so he can do what he feels is in the company's best interest. Other companies can't do that. " the advantage is that the company hasn't had to make money as other do , and built up theirs, to use against AMZN in the future. That's what you buy a company for: you keep expanding a share price without earnings, you just owe shareholders more down the road. And it won't get easier. Their advantage is what could be their trouble: company stock is invested in to make money and a return to shareholders: in the big picture: that involves making money, not merely expanding the share price multiple to a great disparity versus the market: it's a called a return on capital:AAPL just jumped to being able to give some of that return to shareholders in the form of a dividend: a much more stable foundation for a company. AMZN's return on capital to shareholders is on momemtum chasing to now 100's of multiple of decreasing earnings.

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

Message.Msg: "This is Amazon's advantage, JB isn't worried about getting fired, so he can do what he feels is in the company's best interest. Other companies can't do that." JB has created only NEGATIVE value for shareholders. Amazon raised Billions and Billions of cash from shareholders only to create ZERO earnings over the past 20 years. Return on equity has been negative. The only reason to buy this stock is because you believe there will be a bigger fool in the future.

Topic.Title: Sybil rinsed off the blood from slaughtering the pcln pig and sharpended the knives for

Message.Msg: PJ: Another Sybs imposter... Everyone is talking about how the market will keep climbing the wall of worry. More BS Wall Street talk for act in a predatory fashion (in this case shake out weak shorts rather than weak longs). Institutional longs (who are supposedly investors) are the ones who stand to lose the most from the continued erosion of trust. The only way they'll ever get it back is to slowly let the air out of the balloon rather than playing along with the predatory games. We'll see. I'm starting to get the sense that those entrusted with investing our retirement money get it. If so, the market might come back into balance and retail money that has been pulled might start flowing in... It won't help AMZN which is a valuation scam, but the stocks we are long would benefit...

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

Message.Msg: If Apple thought that all its cash was earmarked to come in and save the hides of Amazon shorts why didn't they just go directly into a price war with Amazon over e-books? Why did the feel forced to collude and illegally fix prices? Apple has set aside its cash for its core business which would be to buy up tech companies that will help it create newer generations of their 4 core products. Not to get into price wars with low margin high volume retailers like Amazon and drive its own margins down simply because shorts think "its a good idea."

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

Message.Msg: No, that is easy to understand. It also explains why when pitted against an incumbent with large share already Jobs chose to collude with publishers illegally fixing prices rather than get into a price war with Amazon.

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

Message.Msg: "If Apple thought that all its cash was earmarked to come in and save the hides of Amazon shorts why didn't they just go directly into a price war with Amazon over e-books? Why did the feel forced to collude and illegally fix prices?" Because AAPL likes to sell things for a profit. Unlike AMZN.

Message.Title: Stock futures turning positive.
Message.Msg: Creepy . . . if you were short. I'm not.

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

Message.Msg: OK, I did. It has nothing to do with cash. Ebay is simply partnering with local retailers in one city. The retailers seem to be bearing the burden of fulfillment. Let's see. Retailers after spliting $2.50 with Ebay get to handle all that pick and packing and delivery in a very short window of time and make a business of it. Brilliant. So why didn't they think of this before? Easy. Because they could never figure out a way to do it better than Amazon. What has changed for them then? Did they finally figure out a way all of sudden? No. Amazon is moving into their turf with distribution centers only miles away from consumers. It's simply a kind of last stand desperation defensive move on the part of those retailers. When they find out it is too costly for them to do this they can always cut Ebay out of the equation, too. Shorts told me that anyone can open up a website after all. In fact, all of those retailers already have their own websites but I guess those Silicon Valley types on shop through "real" e-commerce portals, right?

Topic.Title: EBay moves into Amazon Prime territory

Message.Msg: I see, so you don't agree with shorts here that companies like Apple are eager to get into price wars because after all this what their cash is for.
